instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
[PLAIN][SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.[/PLAIN]

Hi guys (again),

This one has been giving me hard time for a while now. It would only run from battery and after some testing with the charger connected it went kinda FUBAR. I replaced <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and noticed that <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> was getting really hot and green light was gone soon after that (also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>). Now having tested most of resistors and various points for shorts I removed F7040 and injected 12V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> pin. If I now connect the charger the fan starts - its also quite funny to watch the system staying on when the charger is afterwards removed (video).

[url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pXYScevrZHU&feature=youtu.be[/url]

It seems the problem lies before the fuse but can't really focus on something.

Hope I am not wasting your time.

George

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message: When apply 12 V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> if you connect charger and it powers on, this means one wire circuit is working.... Also the problem is not on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line.... The problem lies on ISL, maybe isl soldered wrong, replace ISL and output mosfets, also check sense resistors <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> should be 10 ohm each, measure resistance over pins 1 and 2 from <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>, should be 20ohm...... Measure <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> (2.2ohm) and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> (0ohm), resistance over pin 1 and 2 from <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> should be about 3-4ohm...

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message: by the way, youtube video is set as private... I can't see it

threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 2494"]by the way, youtube video is set as private... I can't see it[/QUOTE]

apologies for that: [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pXYScevrZHU[/url] - should be ok now

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
What voltage is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without battery connected?

Does the voltage go  up/down/change over time?

What is the resistance when you measure <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> in resistance mode, no power connected?

What is the resistance when you measure <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> in resistance mode, no power connected?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, no batt, 1,9V now (was higher when I started messing with this board but fluctuating if I remember correctly)

<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>, resistance mode, 2,9ohm
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>, resistance mode, 20ohm

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
OK I took this out of the box again for another try..

Measured <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> at 170ohm instead of 20ohm and replaced it.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 1.2V and L7030 gets REALLY HOT in about 30sec, diode measurement .414 - but EVEN hotter is <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> in 10sec time, which I replaced to no avail.

Diode measurements at <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>: pin2=0, pin1=.234, pin3=.445 both old and new diode.

EDIT: [also replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> - its next in line so although I measured no shortcuts I though it might still cause some high impedance somehow]

Rabbit hole to hell or not?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
If <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is dead then <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is guaranteed dead.

Let's do one thing at a time here. Firstly, the diode mode measurements at <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>, are these across the diode, are these to ground?

Secondly, is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present? 

Thirdly, is there a short to ground on F7040?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 2670"]If <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is dead then <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is guaranteed dead.

Let's do one thing at a time here. Firstly, the diode mode measurements at <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>, are these across the diode, are these to ground?

Secondly, is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

Thirdly, is there a short to ground on F7040?
[/QUOTE]


ok diode measurements to ground (new ones)

pin1: .428
pin2: 0
pin3: .544

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present, green light ok - EDIT: I dont let it stay on for long since <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> gets really hot.

F7040 diode mode starts at .170 and rises slowly to .380 (keeps going one by one but Ill kill myself before it halts)

In the meantime I will replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.


E D I T 2:

Ok it seems I was chasing my tail with this one... I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (again) and the fan spins... Will report back.

Can a bad <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> destroy a new <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?


E   D   I   T    3:

it works!


god damn it.



thank you louis, thank you aprendiz.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only from battery, also not charging - "nice" 40sec video included.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is just a current limiting resistor for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. It is not going to "kill" <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. A bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> will however kill a good <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> does have a <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> pin so it was probably shorting <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground, as well as <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> line which is why <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> was blowing. 

Glad you fixed it!
